nodes.bodyText:
"Log in to your hosting provider" feels wrong - I don't need to log in to a hosting provider to get access to a database
Suggest this is converted into a list of the information you need for the database connection:

Type (MySQL, PostgeSQL, MariaDB, SQLite)
Host (IP address or hostname)
Port (port number on the host at which the database is accessible)
User (username of user with appropriate access to the database)
Password (for the user specified)
Database (Database name to be used)

I think I get where you're going with these comments, but there will be a lot of first-time users who won't understand any of this. So "special" is relative here I think.
What is "appropriate access"? I got errors until I set up the user account to expect calls from my IP; it wasn't just having a username and password (unlike accessing the public Rfam). Is there a way around that? Are there other methods entirely?
If my experience is just a special case, that's great to know - but it's the only datapoint I have so far.  Ideally I can have some volunteers walk through this process (on PostgreSQL or MariaDB or SQLite) and report back.

I agree that there will be a lot of users (first time or not) who won't know how to connect to a database using this process. I don't think your experience is a special case or that it is straightforward to do.
What I should have said is I don't think there are any requirements specific to OpenRefine here. The same issues would apply no matter what client software you were using to connect to the database.  It's probably clear that my view would be configuring the database software with an appropriate user is outside the scope of OR documentation - but I'm very happy for you to do what you think is best.

Sorry I'm being picky but:
"the domain that uses the database" I think should be "or the domain that hosts the database"
And at the risk of re-treading previous discussion:
"you may need to add OpenRefine (connecting from your computer’s IP) to the “allowable hosts” for that account."
I think would be more accurate to say:
"you may need to add the host or IP that OpenRefine is running on to the “allowable hosts” for that account."
Even this I don't think is entirely accurate - because I think the allowable host will need to be the host/IP that the database perceives OpenRefine to be connecting from - which won't necessarily be the IP that is allocated to the computer running OpenRefine

This could include an online catalogue, a Wordpress or similar content management system, or a [digital repository or collection management system](https://bits.ashleyblewer.com/blog/2017/08/09/collection-management-system-collection/).
-
-OpenRefine can connect to PostgreSQL, MySQL, MariaDB, and SQLite database systems. It will automatically populate the “Port” field based on which of these you choose, but you can manually edit this if needed.
-
-To import data directly from a database online, you will need to do two things:
-
-
-
-*   Add OpenRefine (running from your computer) to an account authorized to access your database
-*   Set up OpenRefine to access that database using that account 
+If you are an administrator or have SQL access to a database of information, you may want to pull the latest dataset directly from there. This could include an online catalogue, a content management system, or a digital repository or collection management system. You can also load a `.db` file saved locally.
 
-![A screenshot of connecting to a database](img/databaseconnect.jpg "A screenshot of connecting to a database.")
+There are some publicly-accessible databases you can query, such as [one provided by Rfam](https://docs.rfam.org/en/latest/database.html). The instructions provided by Rfam can help you understand how to connect to and query from any database. 
 
+OpenRefine can connect to PostgreSQL, MySQL, MariaDB, and SQLite database systems. It will automatically populate the “Port” field based on which of these you choose, but you can manually edit this if needed.
 
-Log in to your hosting provider. Get the database type (such as MySQL), database name, and the URL (either an IP address, such as `127.0.0.1`, or the domain that uses the database, such as _https://openrefine.org/category/blog.html_). Then look at the accounts authorized for access. You may wish to create a new account just for OpenRefine, or add OpenRefine to an existing account. 
-
-Each host will have a slightly different method, but generally speaking: look for “accounts with access” to the database you wish to authorize, and within the settings for that account, look for “allowable hosts” or “access hosts.” 
-
-In that list, add the IP address of your own computer, because that is where the OpenRefine access request will be coming from. You can find this easily, by clicking “Test” within OpenRefine once the rest of the information is filled out: OpenRefine will give you an error that looks like 
-
-``` error:Access denied for user 'yourusername'@'123-45-67-89.yourISP.com' ```
+If you have a downloaded database (`.db`) file from an SQLite database, you can supply the path to the file on your computer directly in the “Database” field at the bottom of the form. You can leave the rest of the fields blank.
 
-Take your IP address from this error message and put that, with periods instead of hyphens, into the “allowable hosts” field on the account you’re trying to use. Add a wildcard to the end of your IP address (“123.45.67.89%”). Save that setting, and then test the connection again with OpenRefine.
+To import data directly from a database online, you will need the database type (such as MySQL), database name, and the hostname (either an IP address, such as `127.0.0.1`, or the domain that uses the database) and the port on the host. You will need an account authorized for access, and you may need to add OpenRefine (connecting from your computer’s IP) to the “allowable hosts” for that account.
